thread.section_title: Business News, Economy, Finance & ASX Market News
thread.title: Nightclub boss buying 50 Market Street piece by piece
thread.title_full: Nightclub boss buying 50 Market Street piece by piece

author: Marc Pallisco
title: Nightclub boss buying 50 Market Street piece by piece
text:
Low interest rates are encouraging investment in the strata office market
Young Melbourne entrepreneur Andrew Sirianni is on track to acquiring a mid-rise office building â€“ strata floor by strata floor.
The civil engineer and nightclub owner has snapped up three levels of the former Treasury Funds House at 50 Market Street, in deals speculated to be worth some $8 million.
The Baroqhouse and Bond Bar founder's portfolio already includes another two strata floors in the renovated 46-year old building, which he bought in 2008.
On a 644 square metre block with redevelopment potential, 50 Market Street rises 15 levels and has a lettable area of 7000 square metres, 16 car parks and a valuable ground floor retail component.
Advertisement Office occupants enjoy view security over the low-rise Immigration Museum on Flinders Street to the Yarra River and Southbank.
CBUS Property is also undertaking a major commercial redevelopment of a Collins Street site across the road.
Mr Sirianni is set to rebrand 50 Market Street as Universal House after the successful engineering firm, Universal Corporation, formerly Universal Group, which his family started.
The new office will also act as headquarters for the businessman's hospitality brand, three of Mr Sirianni's venues being a short walking distance away.
CBRE agents Tom Tuxworth and Nick Lower marketed the strata floors at 50 Market Street.
Mr Tuxworth said that ease of access to funds is part of the reason owner occupiers are investing in the strata office market.
"The current low interest rate environment is driving overwhelming demand from owner-occupiers to lock in cheap five year fixed funds and purchase a business premises instead of leasing," Mr Tuxworth said. "Buyers are coupling this with using a self managed super fund as an investment vehicle for tax breaks by leasing the property back to their business".
"Traditional renters are seeking advice from their accountants and financial planners on the benefits of purchasing in such a strong lending market, in many cases saving money this way while growing their property portfolio"
Other companies to invest in the Melbourne CBD strata sector include Rolex, which paid more than $9000 per square metre for a floor at 18 Oliver Lane.
Prestige auction house Sotheby's was another, relocating from South Yarra to a full-floor of 41 Exhibition Street, a strata-office building developed by the Australian Institute of Architects, and which targeted owner-occupier investors.
